newsitem.title: USA: CSCE coffee futures get a boost from ACPC news.
newsitem.headline: CSCE coffee futures get a boost from ACPC news.

text.p: A decision by the Association of Coffee Producing Countries (ACPC) to extend coffee export quotas drove CSCE coffee futures sharply higher Wednesday morning, analysts said.

"Talk the ACPC was loosening quotas was part of the bearish news affecting the market over the last few days," said Allendale analyst Jim Cordier. "The fact they're not going to follow through on that is bullish.
"Coffee consolidated a couple of days and I'm buying coffee on a technical trade here. I expect coffee to go up 10.00 cents today," he added.

The benchmark July contract jumped 7.00 cents per lb as of 0958 EDT, to 247.25 cents, after trading from 248.75 to 239.00. Second-month September was 6.80 higher, at 221.50, while the back months traded up 1.80 to 6.00 lower.
After talks in London on Wednesday, the ACPC put out a statement announcing it set export limits for one year at 52.75 million bags starting July 1.
"The priority of the established policy is to ensure prices remain at a level remunerative to producers, but allowing continuing growth in worldwide consumption of coffee," the ACPC said.
The ACPC said the seasonal allocations of the programme for the whole year would be decided at a later stage, to allow a more flexible and adequate flow of coffee to the market.
But while the market was likely to view the ACPC as friendly, some analysts said its impact should be minimal.
"I don't think this should have an affect on the market," said Smith Barney analyst Walt Spilka. "I don't think it's an overly effective program anyway."
